quote.content:
ğŸš¨ Why Bitcoin always dumps at 10 a.m. when the U.S. market opens ?

Today, Bitcoin erased 16 hours of gains in just 20 minutes after the US market opened.

Since early November, BTC has dumped most of the time after US market opens. The same thing happened in Q2 and Q3.

@zerohedge has been calling this out repeatedly, and he thinks Jane Street is the most likely entity doing this.

When you look at the chart, the pattern is too consistent to ignore: a clean wipeout within an hour of the market opening followed by slow recovery. Thatâ€™s classic high-frequency execution.

And it fits their profile:

â€¢ Jane Street is one of the largest high-frequency trading firms in the world.
â€¢ They have the speed and liquidity to move markets for a few minutes.

The behavior looks simple:

1. Dump BTC at the open.
2. Push the price into liquidity pockets.
3. Re-enter lower.
4. Repeat daily.

And by doing this, they have accumulated billions in $BTC.

As of now, Jane Street holds $2.5B worth of BlackRockâ€™s IBIT ETF, their 5th largest position.

This means most of the dump in BTC isn't due to macro weakness but due to manipulation by one major entity.

And once these big players are done with buying, BTC will continue its upward momentum.

BESSENT: US ECONOMY STRONGER THAN EXPECTED

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told CBS News that the economy is â€œbetter than we thought,â€ predicting 3% GDP growth by the end of 2025. He said President Trump is frustrated by media criticism, noting real incomes are up about 1%. Bessent also claimed the US inherited â€œembedded inflationâ€ from the Biden administration.

tweets.content: The most damning indictment against intellectuals is that any time in history an intellectual class has been given institutional power, it immediately ceases any truly novel intellectual work and becomes entirely devoted to memorizing and producing commentaries on a fixed set of books that constitute their dogma. Oneâ€™s knowledge of these books and the various commentaries on them then becomes the sole mark of an â€œeducatedâ€ person, which crowds out all other forms of intellectual inquiry, whereupon the entire civilization enters a period of stagnation. The Brahmins had the Vedas and Vedic literature, Chinese civil servants had the Four Books and Five Classics, medieval Christian monks had the Bible of course but also Church Fathers such as St Augustine. It was inevitable that, once the West had recreated an institutionalized and self-selected intellectual class in the form of our sprawling university system, this pattern would repeat itself. And it should now be obvious to everyone that the specific books our intellectual class has decided to canonize are the works of Marx, along with several other early Marxist thinkers. That is the dogma our intellectual class has settled upon. Today, the humanities departments of every major university function as a vehicle for the propagation of Marxism just as surely as the Brahmin caste functioned as a vehicle for the propagation of the Vedas or the Chinese civil servant class functioned as a vehicle for the propagation of Confucius. This has happened for the same reasons and is following the same dynamics as every other time in history when it happened before.

quote.content:
As a women in BD, you regularly get pitched for casual sex.

This is a real problem.

Hereâ€™s my experience and how Iâ€™ve coped ğŸ§­ 

For the first 2 years, I wore my company t-shirt religiously like a military uniform. At a talk, during a pitch, or on the conference floor, you will never see me without it.

It worked to a certain extend. As the message cannot be more clear - hi, I am here to work. HOWEVER - because I am Asian and we look young to the untrained eye, with my tech worker backpack, I was regularly passed over during BD events, or assumed to be someone unimportant at the company (I am the founder CEO). Once I even got ID-d. Another time hotel front desk flagged me when I walked in, trying to get valet parking - they mustâ€™ve thought Iâ€™m some confused high schooler who wondered in to the Ritz, where the event was held. 

It still didnâ€™t block all contact. The most extreme case - I had someone who approached me, appearing to want a job. He went on to message me every day on TG and called every other, taking up 40-50 hours of my total time. Maybe even more. At first, I had thought this was just a high profile high maintenance engineer who really enjoyed sharing his life when recruiting - dog, plant, first tattoo, childhood best friend, mom dad ex girlfriend. And I was willing to invest to mentor and build a connection. It wasnâ€™t until I saw his messaging thread with another girl whoâ€™s romantically involved with him a year later, where he sent the exact content, did it hit me that he was, in fact, trying to flirt with me. It was a huge waste of my time.

After that, I started to enter more rooms with senior executives - Sony, Sega, Robinhood, etc. I realized that while very tech coded, looking like a high schooler was making me stand out in a strange way. We autists have a social sense too - just slow and very dull, but itâ€™s there.

I switched strategy. From there on, I always made sure any event I attended, I had a male companion with me. Itâ€™s either my own BD team @nostratbeststra and @Web3LooterBowen, or someone Iâ€™d borrow from a trusted team, such as BD leads from Soneium or Sei. Fortunately or unfortunately - crypto events can be very vibe-y. We once attended a beachside swim and hang with the Ethereum foundation. It was one of the best events at ETH CC hosted by @jchaskin. It was also prime grounds for guys looking at girls in bikinis and asking for ig accounts. Having a trusted contact in these cases usually helps.
(@TatsuatTokyo from Soneium as seen in the photo!) 

Usually, after these bad experiences, I have a mini breakdown, where I feel a pang of fear and anxiety, and end up acting out in one way or another. Sometimes itâ€™s an angry aggressive pitch to a trusted friend (â€œinvest and wire RIGHT NOWâ€ or â€œI need your analyst, DONT FUCKING CAREâ€), other times itâ€™s finding a gay person in the room and clinging on to them tightly. In any case - itâ€™s not fun. 

Alas, this is my experience. I donâ€™t have a solution, but at least, Iâ€™ll talk about my problems.

Happy December!

quote.content:
If you wanna stop losing money in crypto, the first thing you should do is STOP day trading.

Because RETAIL day trading is structurally a SCAM.

This is a long post but if you just give me 120 seconds of your time, I swear you'll thank me in a few years.

Iâ€™ve been trading since I was a teenager.

Iâ€™ve had wins that made me feel Iâ€™m Batman and losses that genuinely broke pieces of me Iâ€™m still putting back together.

I tried EVERY STRATEGY myself as retail could ever find.

I even day traded for a year thinking it would finally save me, and I failed so painfully it still stings every time I remember it.

> My PNL was so shit to the point that my grandma, who I HELPED set up an AUTO BUY on BTC for, made more money than me.

> Then I became a low-frequency swing trader who barely touches positions, who GETS THE F OUT and STOPS TRADING for a while after a winning move.

> ONLY THEN did my life get better and everything finally start to click.

Iâ€™m not a saint. Iâ€™m writing this to save the younger, dumb, naive, and painfully impulsive version of me.

First, as a RETAIL DAY TRADER, youâ€™re trading high-frequency with zero real information advantage (no real order flow, no true liquidity map, no market maker positioning, no execution advantage, nothing).

> Do it a few times each quarter, you survive.
> Do it 10+ times a week?
> Even if you have the strongest â€œdisciplineâ€ and â€œrisk managementâ€ skills in the world, the math will still burry you alive.

Retails donâ€™t fail because they (we) never win.
We fail because we NEVER STOP, and high frequency only has one final outcome.

RUIN.

> This is literally why I built a punishment system for myself if I exceed my quarterly trade limit.

> Every major loss Iâ€™ve ever taken happened after a big win where I kept going instead of stopping.

> And every major win Iâ€™ve ever taken (and actually kept the money for a long time) was because I caught a big move and then CHILLED.

> Pattern is so obvious it hurts.

Winning is NOT you suddenly made big money.
Winning is keeping that money and not fking losing it next year.

> Iâ€™m seeing 14 year olds on TikTok calling themselves day traders, drawing lines on TradingView, thinking they unlocked some daily executable system after buying a guruâ€™s course or Discord.

> It sickens me because if they knew it was gambling I wouldnâ€™t care. At least theyâ€™re aware of the game.

> But this day trading meta is bigger than the dropshipping wave in 2016 and 2017. And we all know how that ended.

> People underestimate the difficulty of trading and massively overestimate their ability.

> The issue isnâ€™t just the math. Yes the more you trade and the less you stop the harder consistent profitability becomes.

> But the real problem is younger retail traders GENUINELY believe that with â€œdisciplineâ€ and â€œrisk managementâ€ they are not gambling at all. They think day trading is a "skill" you can execute like a daily routine.

This isnâ€™t just crypto day trading. The same logic applies to US equities and basically every market.

High frequency only works inside institutions.

> Take US equities for example.
> Do you know what institution traders donâ€™t even look at? Candlestick charts and TradingView.
> Theyâ€™re on Bloomberg terminals with data retail will never see.

Well, you of course knows this. BUT the 14 to 18 year olds donâ€™t know that. They think their indicators are what all traders use.

And thatâ€™s the real danger.
> If you know youâ€™re gambling, at least a part of you knows when to walk away.
> But once you believe itâ€™s a â€œsystemâ€, you never stop.
> You keep clicking until the market empties you completely.

It really is just like a casino in disguise.

> When you walk into Vegas or Macau, you know EXACTLY what youâ€™re stepping into.

> You see the lights, the tables, the dealers, the noise. Your brain knows this is gambling.

> But day trading today is a casino disguised as a COFFEE SHOP.

> New traders walk in thinking theyâ€™re here to â€œlearn a skillâ€, not realizing they just sat down at a table designed to drain them slowly.

So they donâ€™t stop.
Thatâ€™s the whole tragedy.
Not the losing.

The fact that they genuinely believe theyâ€™re not gambling, which makes them keep going until thereâ€™s nothing left to lose.

> And those retail traders (like me) you see who look like theyâ€™re â€œwinningâ€â€¦ honestly most of them just caught a big move.

> They had luck at the right moment, plus enough discipline beaten into them by previous losses that they finally learned how to stop after a win.

And even then, this tiny group is less than one percent of all retail.

Itâ€™s not hard to make money in trading.
Itâ€™s just unbelievably hard to keep it.

If you wanna stop losing money in crypto, the first thing you should do is STOP day trading.

Because RETAIL day trading is structurally a SCAM.

This is a long post but if you just give me 120 seconds of your time, I swear you'll thank me in a few years.

Iâ€™ve been trading since I was a teenager.

Iâ€™ve had wins that made me feel Iâ€™m Batman and losses that genuinely broke pieces of me Iâ€™m still putting back together.

I tried EVERY STRATEGY myself as retail could ever find.

I even day traded for a year thinking it would finally save me, and I failed so painfully it still stings every time I remember it.

> My PNL was so shit to the point that my grandma, who I HELPED set up an AUTO BUY on BTC for, made more money than me.

> Then I became a low-frequency swing trader who barely touches positions, who GETS THE F OUT and STOPS TRADING for a while after a winning move.

> ONLY THEN did my life get better and everything finally start to click.

Iâ€™m not a saint. Iâ€™m writing this to save the younger, dumb, naive, and painfully impulsive version of me.

First, as a RETAIL DAY TRADER, youâ€™re trading high-frequency with zero real information advantage (no real order flow, no true liquidity map, no market maker positioning, no execution advantage, nothing).

> Do it a few times each quarter, you survive.
> Do it 10+ times a week?
> Even if you have the strongest â€œdisciplineâ€ and â€œrisk managementâ€ skills in the world, the math will still burry you alive.

Retails donâ€™t fail because they (we) never win.
We fail because we NEVER STOP, and high frequency only has one final outcome.

RUIN.

> This is literally why I built a punishment system for myself if I exceed my quarterly trade limit.

> Every major loss Iâ€™ve ever taken happened after a big win where I kept going instead of stopping.

> And every major win Iâ€™ve ever taken (and actually kept the money for a long time) was because I caught a big move and then CHILLED.

> Pattern is so obvious it hurts.

Winning is NOT you suddenly made big money.
Winning is keeping that money and not fking losing it next year.

> Iâ€™m seeing 14 year olds on TikTok calling themselves day traders, drawing lines on TradingView, thinking they unlocked some daily executable system after buying a guruâ€™s course or Discord.

> It sickens me because if they knew it was gambling I wouldnâ€™t care. At least theyâ€™re aware of the game.

> But this day trading meta is bigger than the dropshipping wave in 2016 and 2017. And we all know how that ended.

> People underestimate the difficulty of trading and massively overestimate their ability.

> The issue isnâ€™t just the math. Yes the more you trade and the less you stop the harder consistent profitability becomes.

> But the real problem is younger retail traders GENUINELY believe that with â€œdisciplineâ€ and â€œrisk managementâ€ they are not gambling at all. They think day trading is a "skill" you can execute like a daily routine.

High frequency only works inside institutions.

> Take US equities for example.

> Theyâ€™re on Bloomberg terminals with data retail will never see.

Well, you of course knows this. BUT the 14 to 18 year olds donâ€™t know that. They think their indicators are what all traders use.

And thatâ€™s the real danger.
> If you know youâ€™re gambling, at least a part of you knows when to walk away.
> But once you believe itâ€™s a â€œsystemâ€, you never stop.
> You keep clicking until the market empties you completely.

It really is just like a casino in disguise.

> When you walk into Vegas or Macau, you know EXACTLY what youâ€™re stepping into.

> You see the lights, the tables, the dealers, the noise. Your brain knows this is gambling.

> But day trading today is a casino disguised as a COFFEE SHOP.

> New traders walk in thinking theyâ€™re here to â€œlearn a skillâ€, not realizing they just sat down at a table designed to drain them slowly.

So they donâ€™t stop.
Thatâ€™s the whole tragedy.
Not the losing.

The fact that they genuinely believe theyâ€™re not gambling, which makes them keep going until thereâ€™s nothing left to lose.

> And those retail traders (like me) you see who look like theyâ€™re â€œwinningâ€â€¦ honestly most of them just caught a big move.

> They had luck at the right moment, plus enough discipline beaten into them by previous losses that they finally learned how to stop after a win.

And even then, this tiny group is less than one percent of all retail.

Itâ€™s not hard to make money in trading.
Itâ€™s just unbelievably hard to keep it.

å»ºè®®ä½ æŠŠä½ å‘çš„è¿™æ¡æ¨ç‰¹ç›´æ¥å¤åˆ¶ç²˜è´´åˆ° chatGPTï¼Œè®©ä»–æŠŠä½ éª‚é†’ï¼Œä»–å¯èƒ½æ¯”ä½ æ›´åƒäººã€‚

IMPORTANT: A common misconception about OpenAI's upcoming custom chip is that since it is a custom chip, it won't be flexible and will be a dataflow machine. OpenAI has recognized that the 100x efficiency gains for training and inference happen at the algorithm layer, and the hardware chip needs to be flexible enough to accommodate these algorithm changes.

We went from just pre-training transformers to now doing RL post-training on transformers. We went from dense transformers to MoE transformers to soon ultra-sparse transformers that have 4 active experts per token out of 2,048 total experts. We went from causal MHA attention to MQA to GQA to attention sink sliding attention to now even learned sparse attention.

Despite what AI tourists think, the chip OpenAI is building with Broadcom will be far more flexible than TPUs, despite most of OpenAI's chip team being poached from Google's TPU team.

I spent the last week completely off CT. It was amazing.

I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll be posting much here for the next few weeks or months.

I started this account 2 years ago for fun

I had this stupid goal in my head: 100k followers. No idea why. Probably for my ego I guess.

I'm definitely not perfect and can be VERY toxic at times. I can be toxic, I troll, I use sarcasm, I trigger people. And I get why some hate me for it.

But I never did KOL deals and never tried to make money on people following me

I have been called an extractor a shit ton of times during the last few months and if making money makes me an extractor then sure I am

Every time I called something a scam, people got furious which I can understand

I hope I helped some people here on stuff like xUSD and entertained some people following me

I wish you good luck in your journey and see you soon

- CBB

This was indeed a pure scam

quote.content:
If I had money in @gaib_ai, I would withdraw now.

After digging in, I have no clue where funds or collateral actually go.

They even removed the transparency page link from the website. Why?

No 3rd party attestations for 75% of the reserves ($150m).

R/R doesn't look good.

Curate People

0:00 The Best Only Want to Work With the Best
3:49 You'll Never Be Able to Hire Anybody Better Than You
6:45 Break Every Rule to Get the Best People
10:19 It Just Takes a Small Group of People to Create Something Great
14:56 Find Undiscovered Talent Before Everyone Else
19:04 Great People Have Taste in Other People
21:24 Every Great Engineer Is Also an Artist
25:34 Early Teams Look Like Cults
27:59 You Canâ€™t Make a Product that is Simple Enough
30:37 The Founderâ€™s Personality Is the Company
34:45 Good Teams Throw Away Far More Product Than They Keep
38:41 All New Information Starts as Misinformation
40:47 Geniuses Only
44:24 Practice Your Craft At the Edge of Your Capability
49:14 Curate People

tweets.content:
Good Products are Opinionated.

â€œEvery great founder Iâ€™ve seen up close, or even from afar, is highly opinionated and theyâ€™re almost dictatorial in how they run things.

Also, early-stage teams are opinionated. And the products they build are opinionated. Opinionated means they have a strong vision for what it should and should not do.

If you donâ€™t have a strong vision of what it should and should not do, then you end up with a giant mess of competing features.

@Jack Dorsey has a great phrase: â€œLimit the number of details and make every detail perfect.â€ And thatâ€™s especially important in consumer products. You have to be extremely opinionated. All the best products in consumer-land get there through simplicity.

You could argue the recent success of ChatGPT and similar AI chatbots is because theyâ€™re even simpler than Google.

Google looked like the simplest product you could possibly build. It was just a box. But even that box had limitations in what you could do.

You were trained not to talk to it conversationally. You would enter keywords and you had to be careful with those keywords. You couldnâ€™t just ask a question outright and get a sensible answer. It wouldnâ€™t do proper synonym matching, and then it would spit you back a whole bunch of results. That was complicated. Youâ€™d have to sift through and figure out which ones were ads, which ones were real, were they sorted correctly, and then youâ€™d have to click through and read it.

ChatGPT and the chatbot simplified that even further. You just talk to it like a humanâ€”use your voice or you type and it gives you back a straight answer.
It might not always be right, but itâ€™s good enough, and it gives you back a straight answer in text or voice or images or whatever you prefer.

So it simplifies what we looked at as the simplest product on the Internet, which was formerly Google, and makes it even simpler. And you just cannot make a product thatâ€™s simple enough.

To be simple, you have to be extremely opinionated. You have to remove everything that doesnâ€™t match your opinion of what the product should be doing. You have to meticulously remove every single click, every single extra button, every single setting.

In fact, things in the settings menu are an indication that youâ€™ve abdicated your responsibility to the user. Choices for the user are an abdication of your responsibility. Maybe for legal or important reasons, you can have a few of these, but you should struggle and resist against every single choice the user has to make.

In the age of TikTok and ChatGPT, thatâ€™s more obvious than ever. People donâ€™t want to make choices. They donâ€™t want the cognitive load. They want you to figure out what the right defaults are and what they should be doing and looking at, and they want you to present it to them.â€

$AMD Lisa Su gives her opinion on $GOOG TPUs at the UBS Conference:

"Google has done a good job with the TPU architecture over the years. But it is a more purpose-built design. It lacks the programmability, model flexibility, and balanced training and inference capabilities that GPUs offer. GPUs combine a highly parallel architecture with high programmability, which enables fast innovation.

From our perspective, there is room for all types of accelerators. However, over the next five years, GPUs should remain the clear majority of the market because we are still early in the cycle, and software developers want the flexibility to experiment with new algorithms.

You simply cannot know ahead of time what to hard-code into an ASIC. That is the difference. So a 20%â€“25% share for ASIC-style accelerators seems reasonable. It is also important to recognize that this is a large and expanding market, and we will see strong innovation in both silicon and software, which will drive further differentiation across the industry."

ICO meta was sold as a way to give exposure to the community

People now have to fight for tokens at billion USD valuations and should be excited about it

Absolute scam

tweets.content:
Great Engineers are Also Artists.

â€œI characterize art as something that is done for its own sake, and done well, and often creates a sense of beauty or some strong emotion.

And a lot of engineers are introverts.

As an aside, I hate the term â€œincel.â€ Itâ€™s just a way of putting introverts down. Itâ€™s the new â€œnerd,â€ if you will. If someone says that somebody is an incel, Iâ€™m more likely to want to interview them. So letâ€™s move away from the slurs.

But introverts tend to want to express themselves through other things rather than going out and expressing themselves directly. So what are they going to do? Theyâ€™re going to express themselves through their craft. Theyâ€™re going to create art.

In my current company, at least half the engineers have serious artwork theyâ€™ve done on the side. World-class artworkâ€”everything from elegant mathematical proofs to beautiful computer art, to literally sculpting things with clay, designing clothing, designing doorknobs, water bottles. Thereâ€™s one whoâ€™s done incredible music videos, really good stuff. And I see a lot of the better engineers tinker with the AI art products, much more so than even so-called artists do. I think a lot of artists are scared by AI art products saying, â€œThis is going to replace me.â€ Whereas someone who doesnâ€™t have that identity of an artist and doesnâ€™t feel threatened by itâ€”itâ€™s just a tool and they try it out to see what it can create.

Anything done for its own sake and done as well as one possibly can is art. And great engineers are also artists. Theyâ€™re capable of anything. Itâ€™s just theyâ€™ve chosen to be engineers and focused on building things because engineering is the ability to turn your ideas and your art into things that actually work, that do something useful, that embody some knowledge in a way that it can be repeated and people can get utility out of it. But that doesnâ€™t mean that it canâ€™t be beautiful.â€

But introverts tend to want to express themselves through other things rather than going out and expressing themselves directly. So what are they going to do? Theyâ€™re going to express themselves through their craft. Theyâ€™re going to create art.

In my current company, at least half the engineers have serious artwork theyâ€™ve done on the side. World-class artworkâ€”everything from elegant mathematical proofs to beautiful computer art, to literally sculpting things with clay, designing clothing, designing doorknobs, water bottles. Thereâ€™s one whoâ€™s done incredible music videos, really good stuff. And I see a lot of the better engineers tinker with the AI art products, much more so than even so-called artists do. I think a lot of artists are scared by AI art products saying, â€œThis is going to replace me.â€ Whereas someone who doesnâ€™t have that identity of an artist and doesnâ€™t feel threatened by itâ€”itâ€™s just a tool and they try it out to see what it can create.

Anything done for its own sake and done as well as one possibly can is art. And great engineers are also artists. Theyâ€™re capable of anything. Itâ€™s just theyâ€™ve chosen to be engineers and focused on building things because engineering is the ability to turn your ideas and your art into things that actually work, that do something useful, that embody some knowledge in a way that it can be repeated and people can get utility out of it. But that doesnâ€™t mean that it canâ€™t be beautiful.â€

0:00 The Best Only Want to Work With the Best
3:49 You'll Never Be Able to Hire Anybody Better Than You
6:45 Break Every Rule to Get the Best People
10:19 It Just Takes a Small Group of People to Create Something Great
14:56 Find Undiscovered Talent Before Everyone Else
19:04 Great People Have Taste in Other People
21:24 Every Great Engineer Is Also an Artist
25:34 Early Teams Look Like Cults
27:59 You Canâ€™t Make a Product that is Simple Enough
30:37 The Founderâ€™s Personality Is the Company

38:41 All New Information Starts as Misinformation
40:47 Geniuses Only
44:24 Practice Your Craft At the Edge of Your Capability
49:14 Curate People

tweets.content:
â€œGeniuses only.â€

Nivi: To me, the missing ingredient in most peopleâ€™s recruiting is intolerance. You should really just treat every employee in the company, including yourself, as an enemy agent thatâ€™s trying to destroy the company by bringing mediocre talent into the business. Itâ€™s unfortunately just the nature of human nature.

Naval: My co-founder and I have a new criterion in our company: â€œGeniuses only.â€

Itâ€™s a harsh word, but it sets a very high bar. You can just look around for whoâ€™s not a genius. The only way youâ€™re going to attract geniusesâ€”whatever that term means to youâ€”is by having a company full of geniuses.

And if someoneâ€™s not a genius, then either youâ€™re transitioning into the phase where you can no longer hire geniuses and you just need to scale up for whatever reason, or you can just show that person the door because you hired them prematurely for the kind of company youâ€™re trying to build.

Now, this is very difficult.

Youâ€™re lucky if you can hire one genius a month. You as a founder have to identify them and do whatever it takes to recruit them and motivate them. So itâ€™s inherently self-limiting. Given that a person probably isnâ€™t going to stick around your company for more than three, four, five yearsâ€”although in some great companies, people stick around for decadesâ€”at that attrition rate youâ€™re talking about a 30 to 50 person company.

But if you can even assemble a team of 10 geniuses, youâ€™re way ahead of everybody else. At most companiesâ€”the successful onesâ€”the founders, and maybe a few early people are at the genius level. But in the urge and the rush to scale, that gets drowned out too quickly.

Naval: My co-founder and I have a new criterion in our company: â€œGeniuses only.â€

Itâ€™s a harsh word, but it sets a very high bar. You can just look around for whoâ€™s not a genius. The only way youâ€™re going to attract geniusesâ€”whatever that term means to youâ€”is by having a company full of geniuses.

And if someoneâ€™s not a genius, then either youâ€™re transitioning into the phase where you can no longer hire geniuses and you just need to scale up for whatever reason, or you can just show that person the door because you hired them prematurely for the kind of company youâ€™re trying to build.

Now, this is very difficult.

Youâ€™re lucky if you can hire one genius a month. You as a founder have to identify them and do whatever it takes to recruit them and motivate them. So itâ€™s inherently self-limiting. Given that a person probably isnâ€™t going to stick around your company for more than three, four, five yearsâ€”although in some great companies, people stick around for decadesâ€”at that attrition rate youâ€™re talking about a 30 to 50 person company.

But if you can even assemble a team of 10 geniuses, youâ€™re way ahead of everybody else. At most companiesâ€”the successful onesâ€”the founders, and maybe a few early people are at the genius level. But in the urge and the rush to scale, that gets drowned out too quickly.

tweets.content:
We might deposit, but I'm not super excited.

MegaETH said 2.5% of tokens are for the entire farming campaign (not just this pre-deposit).

Bread also mentioned that it could be less than 2.5% for pre-TGE farming iirc.

If they allocate 0.5% of total supply to this pre-deposit vault, at current pre-market price, it's around 56% APR assuming TGE in 45 days.

Decent but definitely not the opportunity of the year.

tweets.content:
We mock boomers for hoarding plastic bags and yellowed receipts stuffed in drawers.

Turns out weâ€™re no different. We just hoard digitally.

Life advice for the dayğŸ‘‡

I spent my Saturday going through my phone and it was straight-up humiliating:

- 98000+ photos Iâ€™ll never look at

- 8000+ chats from 2015 that Iâ€™ll never read but still canâ€™t delete

- A cloud drive drowning in files named â€œfinal_final.docx.â€

Itâ€™s not filling a physical room, so I thought theyâ€™re harmless.

But it ABSOLUTELY takes up space. Just mental space instead.

- Every random screenshot is an unresolved thought.

- Every old chat is a ghost version of you just sitting there.

Reminds me of Jordan Petersonâ€™s book â€œ12 Rules of Lifeâ€.

Rule 6 is "Set your house in perfect order before you criticize the worldâ€.

I couldnâ€™t even set my digital house in order.
How the hell was I supposed to feel in control of anything else?

So I finally forced myself to delete everything I didn't need.

The feeling afterwards was wild. Like I literally dropped 20 pounds off my shoulders. Suddenly I could think clearer. Suddenly my brain had room to breathe.

When's the last time you actually cleaned out your digital life?

Not just organizing it into prettier folders. Actually deleting the stuff that's serving zero purpose except making you feel heavy.

I'm telling you, TRY IT.
The relief hits harder than you think.

tweets.content:
Funny how the same â€œKOLsâ€ screaming "Web3 is the future!â€

â€¦are now posting "Web3 is dead" after a few red candlesğŸ¤¡

Like do you even know why any of this matters beyond a quick cash grab?

Before you declare Web3 dead, maybe ask what it was built to rebel against:

A system so broken most people donâ€™t even realize theyâ€™re trapped in it.

Think about it:

 âƒ Why can fish swim freely, but humans need passports to cross imaginary borders?
 
âƒ If freedom of movement was a God-given right, when exactly did we lose it?

 âƒ If the nation-state only appeared in the 18th century, how did it become the only system after WWII?

 âƒ And when did we accept that only centralized powers could mint currency?

The modern nation-state system has stripped away far too much of what was once God-given freedom for humanity.

Hayek put it simply: money shouldnâ€™t be something only governments control. People should be free to create their own.

There are ~200 countries on Earth today, but how many of them issue currencies people actually trust?

Most are just printing money to cover their own mess while your savings lose value.

Web3 flips that power:
- Everyone can mint.
- Everyone can own.
- Everyone can keep their privacy.
- Smart contracts replace the middlemen taxing trust itself.

Is Web3 perfect? No.
It has scams, flaws, shadows everywhere.

But it also gives humanity something we almost lost: a chance to reroute power without asking permission.

Epicurus said happiness is:
the body free from harm, the soul free from anxiety.

Web3 moves us closer to that than any system weâ€™ve ever had.

So if youâ€™re here, know why.

Because if you canâ€™t even explain it to yourself

â€¦youâ€™ll never explain it to anyone else.

quote.content:
$BTC is the fourth covenant God signed with humanity.

1st: The Old Testament
For the Jewish people.
Exclusive, tribal, bound by bloodline.

2nd: The New Testament
For Christians.
Claimed to be universal, but try joining the Church as a poor Asian farmer in the 17th century.

Gatekept by empire, race, and privilege.

3rd: The Declaration of Independence
For Americans.
Only if you were born with the right passport. Immigration was possible, but costly, rare, and rigged.
Most never stood a chance.

You had to prove your worth through money, education, and luck.

4th: Bitcoin.
For the world.
No race. No priest. No nation.
Just you, belief, and a private key.

You donâ€™t need to be chosen.
You donâ€™t need to be born into privilege.
You donâ€™t need to perform, to beg, to ask.

You opt in â€” by choice, not by blood.

A covenant forged in code and open to all.
This time, the system doesnâ€™t care who you are.

It only asks if you understand what this is.

All it takes is for you to believe â€”
and act.

tweets.content:
When I wrote this in 2024, our thesis @primitivecrypto was that we entered a new regime where the market views Bitcoin as a trillion mcap, high-beta growth tech sister trade instead of a monetary toy. The price action since the March 2024 ATH has validated that framing: $BTC has closely tracked $ARKK with an almost identical return profile

This mental model remains a core principle for how we navigate this cycle. Another signal weâ€™ve tracked closely is the liquidity-profile divergence. Near late cycle tops, Binance OI surges while CME OI declines: institutions simply do not validate the rally. This pattern has repeated across all the recent failed ATH attempts
Crypto natives/offshore retail tend to lag structural macro-liquidity shifts, while institutions positioned holistically across growth tech and global macro, have consistently avoided adding directional exposure, even during the 2025 rallies. Their crypto liquidity is downstream of how growth tech is performing overall (as growth tech is competing with crypto). The gap between Binance and CME OI has been one of the cleanest leading indicators of this cycle

This became even more obvious in the 100k to 90k move: Binance OI stayed flat (even slightly elevated) while CME dropped sharply

Similar to you diet differently for different body composition, liquidity composition defines strategy in this market. "Who is bidding" remains the most important question for any allocator. And this new liquidity regime will tighten even further into onshore risk budgets once the CFTC allows in-kind margin (soon in 2026)
